section.title: Present simple passive
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present simple passive when the people who do the action are not important or unknown.
section.text1: People (it's not important who) make this chocolate in Switzerland.
section.text2: People (we don't know who) steal hundreds of cars every week.
section.text2a: Hundreds of cars are stolen every week.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use it to talk about 'people in general'.
section.text3: People (in general) all over the world recognise his face.
section.text3a: His face is recognised all over the world.

section.title: Present simple passive
section.sectiontitle: If we want to say who or what is the 'doer' of the action, we use by.
section.text1a: All my clothes are designed by Frederico Pirani.
section.sectiontitle2: We use the active when we are more interested in who does something and the passive when we are more interested in the thing/action.
section.text3a: Martine makes all her own bread at home.
section.text4: We are more interested in the <i>thing/action:
section.text4a: The bread is made in a large bakery outside town.

section.title: Present simple passive
section.sectiontitle: In the positive, we use am/is/are + past participle.
section.text2a: Rolex watches are worn all over the world.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use be + not + past participle. In the question, we use be + subject + past participle ...
section.text4a: Is it made out of plastic? Yes, it is.
